The Bibb County School District will continue helping provide students with the necessary internet connection for virtual learning TOMORROW, September 1. This event, part of the District’s participation in the 1Million Project Foundation, will take place from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. at the Professional Learning Center, located at 2003 Riverside Drive.
This distribution of more than 1,500 mobile hotspots as well as a service connection is part of an ongoing effort that began with an initial batch of hotspots in December. Students enrolled in the District in Pre-K through 12th grade are eligible to sign out a device, with a limit of one device per household.

Social distance
Temperature check
Always mask up
Rinse and Wash your hands for 20 seconds

Here's an update on Breanna Ivey, a 2017 IB graduate of Central High School!

Bre is interning with NASA this summer and she is part of a team building a rover that is set to launch to Mars on July 30. See the countdown for Mars 2020 Mission Perseverance Rover at https://mars.nasa.gov/mars2020/!

Here is a description from her of the task and her role: "The Perseverance Rover is the rover that is going to be sent to Mars to explore and gather rock samples with the objective of seeking signs of past life. One of the capabilities of the rover is that with a specific data input, it should be able to travel to that location. I work on the Mobility team as a Test Engineer and my current task is to create test cases and develop procedures that will check all of the data return by the Flight Software Computer concerning where that location is relative to the rover.”

Breanna has enrolled in graduate school and will complete an additional two semesters at Georgia Tech to graduate with a dual graduate and undergraduate degree in Electrical Engineering!

After consultation with the Board of Education, Superintendent Dr. Curtis Jones Jr. has made the decision to end instruction, or eLearning, for the academic year on Friday, May 1. The District will use the time from May 4-22 to engage teachers and staff in professional learning, to finalize grades, and to process the return of students’ digital equipment, textbooks, library books and instruments. Until May 1, though, students will continue learning.
Additionally, the District has made the decision to postpone graduation ceremonies until July 29-30. Officials will reassess health and safety guidelines for large events midsummer. If the District determines it is still unsafe to host the ceremonies in person, each high school will host a virtual ceremony on July 29-30. If the District is able to hold the ceremonies in person on July 29-30, please know these ceremonies will not be the same as they have been in the past.
Please read the full message from Dr. Jones for more specifics: https://www.smore.com/vbc2k
